dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emma lays on one side of the antique double bed, headphon on, computer open in her lap. Bridget sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Wanna come for a drive with Uncle Nicky?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. Uncle Nicky’s a dick.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: No he isn’t. Don’t say that. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you apply for a new dorm?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You did?  22.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh. You’re okay here by yourself? Emma glares.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. I have my cell.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, you do? Really? Great, I’1l call you, we’ll chat. Bridget closes the door and steps into the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget heads down the hall toward the back door. She sto at the ajar bathroom door and peers in.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (in the bathroom; gently) Wait, honey, take your nightie off. In the mirror, Ruth’s arms are in the air, like a child. gently pulls her nightie over her head. She giggles. Bridget watches, touched by his care, until: The back door opens. Nick pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Let’s go, dickie-doodle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick drives west on 290. Bridget sits shotgun in her borr parka, looking at the Chicago skyline ahead.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Jimmy Laciak sits on the board of the best memory place in Chicago, got a waiting list a mile long. He can get Mom in there February one and Dad in a two bedroom on the same campus on the 15th.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: They can’t be together?  23.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Memory care’s lock down, dementia only. It’s a bunch of loons, he’d be ripping his hair out in there anyway. She looks out. They’re downtown now, driving along the El

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Assisted living’s fifty yards away, he can walk over whenever he feels like it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Dad’s doesn’t want assisted living.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s not daycare, Bit, they don’t wipe his ass. It’s great, they do his laundry, give him a meal plan, he gets chest pains he pushes a button. Nick parks the car at a meter on Division Street.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Where do you think, dumdum? She doesn’t know. They get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk down deserted Division.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: What about a live-in person?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Insurance doesn’t cover it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: It doesn’t cover memory care either.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It covers some of it, then they sell the condo.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: He’s not gonna sell the condo.  24.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What’s he gonna do, take it with him? Nick pulls keys from his parka and goes to a door. She’s confused for a moment, then it hits her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh my god! She looks at the sign, awed. It reads NICK'S.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that you? Are you Nick?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s the other owner. His name's Nick too.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Whassa matter with you? Of course it’s me, dingleberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walk in the bar, Bridget’s eyes wide. It’s a gorgeous space, high ceilings, long copper bar, gorgeous mural on wall, tastefully decorated with curated antiques.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Wow. My god, it’s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, see? It’s not some shitty dive.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Who said it was a shitty dive? Nick looks pointedly at her - who does she think?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well has he been here?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Of course he hasn’t been here.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Did you invite him?  25.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have to invite him. Nick walks along the bar to the back and disappears down stairs to the basement. Bridget follows slowly, taking it in, then follows him down into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick sifts through the mess on the desk -- stacks of paperwork, bottles of corked wine, a well-worn book: The Friend’s Approach to Alzheimer’s Care. In the corner of the basement is an unmade twin blow up b

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Somebody's living here.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You're one sharp cookie, Bit.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The other owner. Nick retrieves a folder from the mess and heads out of th office with it. Bridget follows. As they head up the step

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You're living here? What about Rachel? Nick waves her off. INT. NICK'S BAR - NIGHT - A MOMENT LATER. Nick steps behind the bar and tosses a cocktail menu at h

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What do you wanna drink?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (reading from the menu) Norbert’s Manhattan?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Best manhattan you'll have in your life, you’1l shit your pants. He mixes her manhattan and pours it in front of her.  26.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emma’s a real peach these days, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I think she hates me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I dunno. She doesn’t talk to me. She sips her manhattan as Nick rinses the shaker.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (uh-oh) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: In my pants.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Right? That thing’s won awards.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Norbert would be very proud. Nick pours himself neat Irish whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened with Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh who knows. All of a sudden she’s bursting into tears over a hamburger ‘cause I haven't proposed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: She's been waiting for you to want to marry her, dummy. Nobody wants to ask to be proposed to. (then) You gotta be intuitive, it’s like Eddie, right, I’m constantly telling him how chefs hate kitchen gadgets and what does he put under the tree for me every year?  27.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s cause you open it and go wow! A coconut roaster! Oh my god thank you I love it!

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Well what am I supposed to say?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No thanks, where’s the receipt?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I can’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna make him feel bad in front of the girls.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You know what you’re saying to the girls? His feelings matter, mine don’t. (then) That's exactly what this world needs, two more women who don’t tell you what’s really going on. Two more Rachels.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: She told you what’s going on. Go over there. Bring her flowers.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m not goin’ over there. She hasn’t even called.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: She shouldn’t have to call. Nick frowns. Touche.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, now she’s trying to get full custody of her kid, so.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So what am I, gonna go be a parent?  28.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Why not? What do you think I got goin’ on here? I got my life savings is dumped into this business and I’m barely making payroll, I got the fire department and the health department double, triple fining me for the same shit I didn’t even do, I got a barback stealing tips and then - and then - I’m filling Mom and Dad’s prescriptions. I’m picking up their dry cleaning. I’m taking ‘em to church. He downs his drink.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She knows I don’t want kids, that’s the whole reason we broke up six years ago. Here. He tosses the folder from his office across the bar to he

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I filled it all out, all he’s gotta do is sign. The folder reads THE REMINISCENCE NEIGHBORHOOD. Beaming OCTOGENARIANS sit by a fire around a Parcheesi bo She opens it. Inside is a brochure and stack of paperwork

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: The Reminiscence Neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: They're all called shit like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget and Nick step out of Nick’s car. He lights a smok and tosses the Reminiscence folder across the hood to her

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Here we go now. Put your big girl pants on.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Just - don’t get how you get.  29.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What do you mean, how I get? Don’t get how you get.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: How do I get?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You can’t even tell him you're not a Catholic anymore. What’s he gonna do, pray for you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I just didn’t want any more of the third degree.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You know what I do when Dad gives me the third degree? Nick thrusts two middle fingers into the air.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: See? That’s how you get.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Least I’m not lying to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m not lying to him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You are too.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I am not. They go through the back gate of the condo into the court toward the condo’s back steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert sits in his recliner, scotch in hand, staring at the tree. When he hears the sound of the back door opening, h quickly grabs the paper and pretends to read it. Bridget walks in. Bert looks over and sees Nick behind he wrinkles his nose and waves the paper in front of his fac

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Smell like an ashtray, Nicholas.  30.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Took you four heart attacks to quit.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Rachel must wanna throttle you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: They broke up. Nick glares at Bridget. She shrugs. Pointedly:

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just being honest.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I don’t blame her. Been on and off since high school, shit or get off the pot.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Gee, Dad, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, waiting for some feeling. There’s no bells and whistles. You pick somebody you can stand and you make a commitment.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Have her meet us at Mass in the morning. Marion Down The Hall’s coming over with a corned beef.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: We need to talk about Mom. Bert scowls and puts down the footrest of his recliner.  31.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Goddamn teaching hospitals, that little girl shouldn’t have been allowed anywhere near your mother.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What little girl?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: The teenager calling herself a doctor. Your mother’s doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Wandering off in the middle of the night’s doing fine?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Well I gave her too much scotch, if you wanna know, which I never do but it was Christmas Eve so I said what the hell.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So what, she walked off ‘cause she was drunk?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Can't drink hardly at all on her medications.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No. She walked off ‘cause that’s what happens with stage six.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Oh those stages are horse shit, everybody's brain is different and everybody knows it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Everybody except the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: She was not a doctor! Bridget shoots Nick a look and steps in to peace-keep.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: So, okay, we get a second opinion.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Got an appointment next week with her geriactrician down in Florida, I’1l let you know what he says.  Nick gets loud.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Goddammit, Dad, you’re not goin’ to Florida.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: We are too going to Florida --

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You’re gonna wake Mom.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I already put down a deposit! 32. Bridget puts a hand up to Nick, telling him to back off.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Dad, listen. There’s this - place Nicky found, it looks --

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I am not putting your mother in a nursing home, she worked thirty years in nursing homes, they’re horrible and I’m not doing it to her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s not a nursing home. It’s a Reminisce Neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: A what? Nick holds the folder out to Bert. He doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s great. They got Mass twice a week, a restaurant, art classes, a Jacuzzi --

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: A Jacuzzi? Your mother can’t swim, you wanna drown her? Nick chucks the folder on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: She’s not gonna drown in a Jacuzzi.  33.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: She’s terrified of water, Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: She used to be terrified of Berwyn too, now she’s walkin’ down there in a nightie. Bert rolls his eyes and starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two bedroom next door for you, fifty feet away in assisted living. Bert leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Are you outta your mind?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Bitty feels the same way.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Don’t you tell me what Bitty feels, how the heck do you know what she feels? Nick looks expectantly at Bridget.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I - Dad, I think this is a good solution that is worth considering.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Well, I spent the last eight years considering it and the answer’s no. Thanks for the suggestion, Merry Christmas, I’m going to bed. Bert heads toward the hall. Nick flails toward Bridget, demanding her to speak. She flails back at him. She spoke

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: She is wandering off in the middle of a fucking snowstorm. Bert has overheard. From down the hall:

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Doesn’t snow in Florida. (then) And mind your language.  34. Nick glares at Bridget. He turns and heads down the hall, pulling out his smokes. Bridget grabs an afghan from the couch and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick smokes on the back porch. Bridget is next to him, wrapped in the afghan.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: We can’t force him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You know why she wound up in Aurora? That’s the train used to run to Amboy. Her dad worked that train. (then) She was trying to go home. It takes Bridget’s breath away.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She thinks she’s a little kid. Thinks her parents are worried sick about her. He drags on his cigarette and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All she wants is to get back to her poor mother. She can’t figure out why she’s stuck here, all alone with some strange old man. (then) What the hell do you think power of attorney is for? Emotional, Nick hops the railing and heads toward his car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget slips into the dark guest room. Emma’s in bed. Th Reminiscence folder has been shoved under the door. Bridg puts it with her belongings and pulls out pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget is in the living room looking at all the pictures the tree. She bends down to see the two gifts underneath.  35. One is marked TO RUTH FROM BERT, the other TO BERT FROM R in the exact same block handwriting. Bert enters in his pajamas and robe, surprised to see her

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Thought you went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I did. I got back up.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Nice tree.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Your mother likes the pictures. (then) She put the ornaments somewhere, so. I got creative.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Both these presents have your handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t want her thinking she forgot to get me something. (then) C’mon, I’1l let you win a game.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You're not too tired?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: For my daughter who never visits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and Bridget sit on chairs-on-wheels at the table, playing a game of Chinese Checkers.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Emma said she got kicked outta her dorm.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: She got caught drinking, it was so stupid. You know what her problem is? She’s negative. She doesn’t get any exercise.  36.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Her problem is she’s not a student. College is a waste of money if you’re not a student.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Well. She’s gotta get a degree.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Oh she does not, she’ll figure it out, look at you, you figured it out. (then) Why can’t you sleep? He’s asking out of concern, but she sees her in. Pointed:

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Why can’t you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I can. He’s defensive. He doesn’t want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You take great care of her. I aughtta be here more.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Oh you’re here plenty. You got a family, the girls need you, Eddie needs you, you got that job. You’re halfway across the country for chrissake. (then) We're fine. Marion Down The Hall takes her on poker night and so forth. Two peas in a pod, the two of ‘em, both battier than hell.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Still. It’s gotta be hard on you.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Nah. She was always a pain in the ass. Gettin’ her Irish up, stompin’ around all red in the face about God knows what. (then) No bells and whistles. Love is commitment. Better or worse, sickness and health, death do you part. That’s the promise.  37. Bridget nods. Treading carefully:

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: She’s gonna get worse, Dad. (then) She's gonna forget everything. He stares down into his scotch for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: She's my girl, Bit. You can’t take my girl away from me. It breaks her heart. He rises from the table, emotional.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turn the tree off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHOIR leads the congregation in “Joy To The World.” MAR DOWN THE HALL is among them. She’s Italian, dyed black ha huge yellow tinted glasses. Bert, Ruth, Emma, Nick and Bridget stand in a pew near th front. They all sing. The PROCESSIONAL walks the aisle. ALTAR BOYS fling Holy W from palm fronds. Ruth looks skyward and holds out her pa

dialogues.text: It’s raining in here. A CRANKY OLD COUPLE in front turns around to give Ruth a dirty look. She flips them the bird. Bert snatches her ha

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Bitty Keller? THE VOICE -- is walking toward her from the left side of church. He’s 40s, Irish, built.  38.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: (pointing at himself) It’s Gerry! Hoffsteader! Dommie’s little brother? Dommie’s little brother never looked like that before.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: What the heck’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m just, I’m, you know... She gestures at the altar. He clocks that she’s ring-less

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hanging out, me and Mary. Gerry nods, smiling like he gets that answer.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gosh, you look - really great.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: (nodding) Construction. I took over for Dad. His eyes mist. He looks toward the altar reverently.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Death comes for everybody, as it turns out. Bridget nods like she gets that comment.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK OF THE CHURCH -
dialogues.text: Nick stands in the aisle, near the back doors, watching t

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Bitty! Bridget and Gerry turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Hey Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey Ger. Bert marches in, cranky. Emma trots behind him.  39.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Get your sister. He turns and marches out. Nick looks at Emma.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Grama drank the Holy Water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick’s SUV is parked a ways up the street. The family wal towards it, Emma holding Ruth’s purse. Gerry trots behind them, then crosses to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: GERRY
dialogues.text: Um. Bye. Bridget and Nick turn and wave.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: See ya Ger.

dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.text: Gerry Hoff-sniffer.

dialogues.text: Don’t call him that.

dialogues.text: Says Dommie.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I have it, Gram.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (re: Gerry) He was so tubby in junior high.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: So were you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Old Big Butt Bitty.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Does somebody have my purse?

dialogues.text: Marion sits grandly at one end of the table, holding cour Ruth is next to her. Nick and Bert read the paper at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: So I said to Margie, I said Margie honey he’s a toddler, one day he likes pancakes, next day he won't touch the things, it’s normal -- Bridget brings in two plates of corned beef and cabbage a sets them down in front of Nick and Bert.

dialogues.text: Bridget, honey, you’re so skinny, don’t they feed you in California? Bridget heads back into the KITCHEN and hovers over Emma she slices the corned beef.

dialogues.text: Thinner. Thinner. Emma slams the knife down and glares at her mother. Emma grabs two completed plates and goes into the dining room. Bridget slices the last piece and brings the two la plates into the DINING ROOM. She sits next to Emma.

dialogues.speaker: MARION

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ruth’s face relaxes. She pads softly out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth crawls into bed, rousing Bert.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Stay in bed, honey.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You're a turkey.

dialogues.text: You're the turkey. He pulls her close. Bridget watches from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget and Emma sleep. On the night stand, her cell phon vibrates. Bridget reaches over and grabs it. It’s Eddie. She sends to voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget brushes her teeth. Her phone is on the counter, playing Eddie’s voicemail on speaker. EDDIE’S VOICEMAIL Hi, um, your father just called. Bridget stops brushing and stares at the phone. EDDIE’S VOICEMAIL (CONT'D) He said you’re coming home tonight? Gimme a call. Bridget stares at the phone. Then she chucks the toothbru at the mirror and marches DOWN THE HALL.  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridget peers in, looking for Bert. Ruth is peering at pictures on the tree. She sees Bridget.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Is that my baby? Bridget ignores her and heads around the foyer corner int the KITCHEN DOORWAY. Bert is pouring a cup of coffee. Bags of groceries sit on counter. Bridget stands in the doorway and seethes at him He holds the coffee out to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I don’t want it.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: It’s coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I don’t want it.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: A course you want it. Here. She explodes.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I am a grown-up! If I don’t want the coffee I don’t want the coffee! He plops the coffee on the counter and goes to his grocer

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you tell him? Ruth wanders in.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Nobody. Go turn on the Road Runner. Ruth wanders out.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told him I bought you plane tickets and to pick you up at the airport, that’s what I told him.  82. He unpacks his groceries angrily, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Floozin’ around with some construction bozo, I don’t even know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: He put locks on, Dad, and you’re welcome by the way. Bert slams down a can of peas.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: What am I, some horse’s ass? He returns to his groceries.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eddie is as much a son to me as your brother is.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I think you like Eddie more than you like me. And my brother, for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Oh for chrissake, Bitty, what kinda thing is that to say? (then) Go get packed, we’re leavin’ in an hour. He exits the kitchen. She follows him down the HALL -- pa the DEN, where Ruth watches the Road Runner -- and into t

dialogues.text: She shuts the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: All my life you've been telling me, there’s no bells and whistles, there’s no bells and whistles.

dialogues.text: There isn’t.

dialogues.text: How can you say that? You have more bells and whistles than anybody.  83. She’s losing her mind and you still can’t live without her. Didn’t you want that for me?

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: Of course I wanted that for you, that’s all I want for you, why do you think I’m sending you home? (then) Love is commitment, Bit, you work at it.

dialogues.text: I been working at it for 20 years.

California, that’s what, everybody out there flowin’ in the wind, re- inventing, what the heck is that? You are who you are. dialogues.text: Why were you unhappy in your perfectly good Camry? He looks at her, appalled at the comparison.  84.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna look at you. Go sit with your mother.

dialogues.text: I never said I was leaving, I’m saying I don’t have what you have.

dialogues.text: You do too! You think we didn’t have rough patches? You aughtta go talk to a priest.

dialogues.text: I’m not a Catholic anymore.

dialogues.text: How do you know? He looks at her, startled.

(losing it) Why did I never matter? I’m capable, I coulda done something, I- - Mom was a feminist for chrissake, didn’t it occur to anybody to ask me what I wanted? Bert is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Mom! There is no sign of Ruth. Bridget sprints across the lawn A moment later, Emma races down the walkway behind her.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Mom! Bridget whips around to Emma.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Ooh!

dialogues.speaker: BERT

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That’s you ‘n me.

dialogues.speaker: BERT
dialogues.text: That’s right. You ‘n me. He struggles not to get emotional.  91.

dialogues.speaker: BERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (brightly) So when you forget, you can just look at it. All right? Tears well in her eyes. She knows exactly what he means. throws her arms around him and holds him tight.

dialogues.speaker: BERT

dialogues.text: Happy New Year. Over Emma, they share a perfunctory kiss. INT. BRIDGET AND EDDIE’S HOUSE - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT Bridget reclines in bed with cookbooks, copying recipes i a notebook. Eddie comes in and begins to get ready for be

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Eddie turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You didn’t write him a check for 1500 bucks?

dialogues.text: Did I? Open it, they said it was new.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Oh. Maybe it has a new feature or -- She opens the lid of the box. Inside, nestled in tissue paper, is a sizable diamond ring in an open jewelry box.

dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: You are such a good man. That was one of the most romantic gestures I can imagine. (then) The problem is... what is so, so awful is... how much worse I feel now than before you gave it to me. Eddie shakes his head, endlessly frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I have no clue what to do for you. You are never happy, never.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Do you want to leave?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No. I made a promise. I’m a loyal person.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: So am I. That’s the thing. dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Mary starts toward her car, enraged. Bridget follows.

dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.text: Talk to me.

dialogues.text: Bridget comes out of the funeral home carrying a flower arrangement. Nick sits on a curb, smoking a cigarette. She joins him. They sit quietly. And then Nick loses it. She puts her arms around him and holds him as he cries. INT. ST. GILES’S CATHOLIC CHURCH - DAY Bert’s casket is closed at the altar, American Flag drape over the top. Sunlight streams in the stained glass. Bridget stands at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: My dad grew up on a farm in a small town called Amboy. He met Ruth O'Shea at an ice cream social and had a thing for her ever since - even though she wouldn’t give him the time of day. After high school, Dad went off to Korea. When he came home on leave, his mother told him poor Ruthie O’Shea had gotten polio and hadn’t been out of bed in six months. Dad marched over there, picked her up out of bed and carried her, in his arms, to the movies. (then) That was that. He never let her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mourners are huddled. It’s a bitter cold day in Amboy An ANCIENT VETERAN, light blue jacket over his dress blue plays Taps on a trumpet. An AIR FORCE OFFICIAL hands Ruth Bert's American Flag. The final note of Taps hangs over the endlessly flat snow TWO OFFICERS fire their weapons once, and then again.  101. There is silence. And then the creaking of the casket bei lowered into the ground.

dialogues.text: She was not fat.

dialogues.text: Lemme see it.  102. Mary walks to the full-length mirror. The dress is huge o her, and kind of hideous, but it’s perfect.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I will never understand how he could look me in the eye and tell me there’s no bells and whistles when they had what they had.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well how would he know? She was the only person he ever tried to love. He didn’t know he hit the jackpot. He thought it’d be that good with anybody. Bridget stands there, mind totally blown.

dialogues.text: Nick and Bridget stare each other down over reading glass The table is strewn with a sea of documents and coffee cu

dialogues.text: I don’t hate the car. (then; relenting) How would you even get it to California?

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I’m gonna drive it. (then) With Mom. Nick blinks at her.

dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.text: It is bright and cheery. On one wall, a BUS STOP sign sit above a bench. A LADY sits primly on it, purse in her lap A FEMALE AIDE walks through a doorway and smiles at Ruth.

dialogues.text: Is that my baby? She throws her arms around the aide. The aide hugs her ba waving at Bridget over Ruth’s shoulder.
